      • minSegments

        public int minSegments()

      • entrySize

        public ChronicleMapBuilder<K,V> entrySize(int entrySize)

        Note that the actual entrySize will be aligned to 4 (default entry alignment). I. e. if you set entry size to 30, the actual entry size will be 32 (30 aligned to 4 bytes). If you don't want entry size to be aligned, set entryAndValueAlignment(Alignment.NO_ALIGNMENT).

        Parameters:
        entrySize - the size in bytes
        Returns:
        this ChronicleMapBuilder back
        See Also:
        entryAndValueAlignment(Alignment), entryAndValueAlignment()

      • entrySize

        public int entrySize()

      • entryAndValueAlignment

        public ChronicleMapBuilder<K,V> entryAndValueAlignment(Alignment alignment)
        Specifies alignment of address in memory of entries and independently of address in memory of values within entries.

        Useful when values of the map are updated intensively, particularly fields with volatile access, because it doesn't work well if the value crosses cache lines. Also, on some (nowadays rare) architectures any misaligned memory access is more expensive than aligned.

        Note that specified entrySize() will be aligned according to this alignment. I. e. if you set entrySize(20) and Alignment.OF_8_BYTES, actual entry size will be 24 (20 aligned to 8 bytes).

        Parameters:
        alignment - the new alignment of the maps constructed by this builder
        Returns:
        this ChronicleMapBuilder back
        See Also:
        entryAndValueAlignment()

      • entryAndValueAlignment

        public Alignment entryAndValueAlignment()
        Returns alignment of addresses in memory of entries and independently of values within entries.

        Default is Alignment.OF_4_BYTES.

        See Also:
        entryAndValueAlignment(Alignment)

      • putReturnsNull

        public ChronicleMapBuilder<K,V> putReturnsNull(boolean putReturnsNull)
        Map.put() returns the previous value, functionality which is rarely used but fairly cheap for HashMap. In the case, for an off heap collection, it has to create a new object (or return a recycled one) Either way it's expensive for something you probably don't use.
        Parameters:
        putReturnsNull - false if you want ChronicleMap.put() to not return the object that was replaced but instead return null
        Returns:
        an instance of the map builder

      • putReturnsNull

        public boolean putReturnsNull()
        Map.put() returns the previous value, functionality which is rarely used but fairly cheap for HashMap. In the case, for an off heap collection, it has to create a new object (or return a recycled one) Either way it's expensive for something you probably don't use.
        Returns:
        true if ChronicleMap.put() is not going to return the object that was replaced but instead return null

      • removeReturnsNull

        public ChronicleMapBuilder<K,V> removeReturnsNull(boolean removeReturnsNull)
        Map.remove() returns the previous value, functionality which is rarely used but fairly cheap for HashMap. In the case, for an off heap collection, it has to create a new object (or return a recycled one) Either way it's expensive for something you probably don't use.
        Parameters:
        removeReturnsNull - false if you want ChronicleMap.remove() to not return the object that was removed but instead return null
        Returns:
        an instance of the map builder

      • removeReturnsNull

        public boolean removeReturnsNull()
        Map.remove() returns the previous value, functionality which is rarely used but fairly cheap for HashMap. In the case, for an off heap collection, it has to create a new object (or return a recycled one) Either way it's expensive for something you probably don't use.
        Returns:
        true if ChronicleMap.remove() is not going to return the object that was removed but instead return null
